Indicator Description: Forest area (indexed to base year)
Source Description: The data used for our calculations are obtained from the World Bank's World Development Indicators (these coincide with the FAO database). Raw data from WDI are in square kilometres, which we indexed to the base year 1990. For Ethiopia, 1990-1993 values were extrapolated based on the 1993-2010 trend to correct for a trend break due to a change in total land area.
References: FAO / WDI (2016). World Development Indicators. Data retrieved through World Bank website (Last Updated: 12/12/2016)

Indicator Description: Amount of cement produced per capita
Source Description: Cement production activity was calculated by dividing domestic cement production by the national population. Cement production data  for Brazil, China, India, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Turkey, USA and the World were taken from the USGS (USGS 2019), cement production data for Argentina, Australia, Canada, EU, Mexico, South Africa, France, Germany, Italy and the UK was collected from Cembureau (2018; 2019) and for Chile, Kazakhstan, New Zealand, Peru and Ukraine cement production data was collected from UN Data (2017). Production data for Japan for the period 1990-1997 were taken from Statistics Japan (2009). Else, all data before 2015 was collected from USGS (2012; 2016; 2017). National population data were obtained from the UN (UN, 2019).
References:
USGS, Cement (2019). Available at: https://prd-wret.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/assets/palladium/production/s3fs-public/atoms/files/mcs-2019-cemen_0.pdf

Cembureau Avtivity Report (2018; 2019). Available at: https://cembureau.eu/media/1818/actvity-report-2018.pdf

UN Data, cement production (2017). Available at: http://data.un.org/Data.aspx?d=ICS&f=cmID%3A37440-0

UN,  World Population Prospects: The 2019 Revision (2019). Available at: https://population.un.org/wpp/

USGS. (2016). Advance Data Release of the 2014 Annual tables.  Retrieved from http://minerals.er.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/cement/myb1-2014-cemen-adv.xlsx

USGS. (2017). Mineral Commodity Summaries. Retrieved retrieved from https://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/cement/mcs-2017-cemen.pdf

Indicator Description: CO2 emissions per unit cement produced
Source Description: The main source of this analysis was the Global Cement Database (WBCSD, 2017). This database provides intensities for different types of cement and related products. We used data on "Weighted average net CO2 emission per tonne cementitious". These data do not include emissions from electricity consumption, but the same database provides data on electricity consumption per tonne cement. To calculate scope 2 emissions, the electricity consumption per tonne of cement is combined with national average CO2 emission factors of electricity generation from IEA (IEA, 2018).The WBCSD data do not cover all cement installations in a country and data on countries with a low coverage have larger uncertainties. For example in India, 45% of the production is covered, in the USA and Brazil more than 70% and in the EU and Canada more than 90%. We have excluded the data for China, because only a few percent of the cement production is covered in the database. Cement production data were taken from the USGS (USGS, 2012; USGS, 2016; USGS, 2017; USGS, 2019). Production data for Japan for the period 1990-1997 were taken from Statistics Japan (2009).
References:
Cembureau Avtivity Report (2018; 2019). Available at: https://cembureau.eu/media/1818/actvity-report-2018.pdf

UN Data, cement production (2017). Available at: http://data.un.org/Data.aspx?d=ICS&f=cmID%3A37440-0

UN,  World Population Prospects: The 2019 Revision (2019). Available at: https://population.un.org/wpp/

WBCSD Cement Sustainability Initiative. (2017). Global Cement Database - GNR Project; 

IEA, CO2 Emissions from fuel combustion (2018). Available at: https://www.iea.org/statistics/co2emissions/ 

USGS. (2012). 2012 Minerals Yearbook - Cement. Retrieved from http://minerals.usgs.gov/minerals/pubs/commodity/cement/

Indicator Description: CO2 emissions in chemical sector per added value
Source Description:
For value added and for most countries World Bank data (World Bank, 2019) was used. The fraction of chemicals of total GVA of the manufacturing was multiplied by the total GVA of the manufacturing sector, which was obtained by combining the share of manufacturing in GDP (World Bank, 2019) with the total GDP (World Bank, 2019) (in PPP terms). 

As process emissions from the chemical sector are significant, we only included countries for which both process and energy emission data were available. This is the case for Annex 1 countries only and data were derived from the UNFCCC (UNFCCC, 2019), where we used data on category 1AA2C. Other direct emissions were drawn from the 2018 IEA Balances (IEA, 2018). 
We calculated scope 2 emissions by multiplying total electricity consumption in chemical and petrochemical sector from IEA energy balances (IEA, 2018) with national average CO2 emission factors of electricity generation from IEA CO2 emissions data (IEA, 2018).
References:
World Bank, World Development Indicators (2017). Available at: https://databank.worldbank.org/source/world-development-indicators#
IEA, World Energy Balances (2018). Available at: https://www.iea.org/statistics/balances/

Name of Indicator: Coal share in chemical and petrochemicals industry
Indicator Description: Share of coal in energy consumption
Source Description: The share of coal of total final energy consumption was calculated by dividing the national total final coal consumption in the chemical and petrochemical industry (IEA, 2019) by the total final energy consumption in the chemical and petrochemical industry (IEA, 2019).
References: IEA, World Energy Balances (2019). Available at: https://www.iea.org/statistics/balances/

Indicator Description: CO2 emissions in chemical sector per added value
Source Description:
For value added and for most countries World Bank data (World Bank, 2019) was used. The fraction of chemicals of total GVA of the manufacturing was multiplied by the total GVA of the manufacturing sector, which was obtained by combining the share of manufacturing in GDP (World Bank, 2019) with the total GDP (World Bank, 2019) (in MER terms). 

As process emissions from the chemical sector are significant, we only included countries for which both process and energy emission data were available. This is the case for Annex 1 countries only and data were derived from the UNFCCC (UNFCCC, 2019), where we used data on category 1AA2C. Other direct emissions were drawn from the 2018 IEA Balances (IEA, 2018). 
We calculated scope 2 emissions by multiplying total electricity consumption in chemical and petrochemical sector from IEA energy balances (IEA, 2018) with national average CO2 emission factors of electricity generation from IEA CO2 emissions data (IEA, 2018).
References:
World Bank, World Development Indicators (2017). Available at: https://databank.worldbank.org/source/world-development-indicators#
IEA, World Energy Balances (2018). Available at: https://www.iea.org/statistics/balances/

Indicator Description: Amount of steel produced per capita
Source Description: Historical data on steel production were taken from the World Steel Association (2018). Aggregated steel production from EU countries was collected from Eufer(2017, 2018 and 2019). National population data were obtained from the UN (2019). The intencity was obtained by divding production data by population data.

Worldsteel. (2016). Crude steel production, 1980-1999. Available at: https://www.worldsteel.org/en/dam/jcr:3e275c73-6f11-4e7f-a5d8-23d9bc5c508f/Steel+Statistical+Yearbook+2017.pdf

Worldsteel. (2018). Crude steel production, 2000-2018. Available at: https://www.worldsteel.org/internet-2017/steel-by-topic/statistics/steel-data-viewer/P1_crude_steel_total/CHN/IND

Eufer, European Steel in Figures (2017; 2018; 2019). Available at: http://www.eurofer.org/News&Events/PublicationsLinksList/201705-SteelFigures.pdf

UNFCCC, GHG emissions data (2019). Available at: https://di.unfccc.int/flex_annex1

IEA. (2018a). Based on IEA data on World Energy Statistics and Balances 2016 Â© OECD/IEA[2016], www.iea.org/statistics, Licence: www.iea.org/t&c; as modified by the Climate Action Tracker.

IEA. (2018b). Based on IEA data on CO2 From Fuel Combustion Â© OECD/IEA[2016], www.iea.org/statistics, Licence: www.iea.org/t&c; as modified by the Climate Action Tracker.

Indicator Description: CO2 emissions per unit steel produced
Source Description: Historical data on steel production were taken from the World Steel Association (2016 & 2018). For Aggreagted steel production from EU countries, data was collected from Eufer (2017; 2018; 2019). Both scope 1 and scope 2 (emissions related to electricity consumption) emissions are included. For Annex 1 countries, scope 1 emissions, both energy-related and process emissions, were derived from the UNFCCC (UNFCCC, 2015), where we used data on category 1AA2A and 2C1. In case UNFCCC data were not available, IEA data (IEA, 2016a) were used to calculate  energy-related emissions. Direct emissions related to energy consumption were taken from IEA CO2 emissions data (IEA, 2016b). For all countries scope 2 emissions was calculated by multiplying total electricity consumption in the iron and steel sector, from IEA energy balances (IEA, 2016a) with national average CO2 emission factors of electricity generation from IEA CO2 emissions data (IEA, 2016b).
References:
Worldsteel. (2016). Crude steel production, 1980-1999. Available at: https://www.worldsteel.org/en/dam/jcr:3e275c73-6f11-4e7f-a5d8-23d9bc5c508f/Steel+Statistical+Yearbook+2017.pdf

Worldsteel. (2018). Crude steel production, 2000-2018. Available at: https://www.worldsteel.org/internet-2017/steel-by-topic/statistics/steel-data-viewer/P1_crude_steel_total/CHN/IND

Eufer, European Steel in Figures (2017; 2018; 2019). Available at: http://www.eurofer.org/News&Events/PublicationsLinksList/201705-SteelFigures.pdf

UNFCCC, GHG emissions data (2019). Available at: https://di.unfccc.int/flex_annex1

IEA. (2018a). Based on IEA data on World Energy Statistics and Balances 2016 Â© OECD/IEA[2016], www.iea.org/statistics, Licence: www.iea.org/t&c; as modified by the Climate Action Tracker.

IEA. (2018b). Based on IEA data on CO2 From Fuel Combustion Â© OECD/IEA[2016], www.iea.org/statistics, Licence: www.iea.org/t&c; as modified by the Climate Action Tracker.

Indicator Description: Energy-related CO2 emissions per GVA
Source Description:
For Industry GVA data from the World Bank's World Development Indicator Database was used (World Bank, 2019). We multiplied industry GVA as a percentage of total GDP) by total GDP (in PPP terms).
Scope 1 and 2 CO2 emissions from industry were drawn from the IEA World Energy Statistics and Balances; CO2 Emissions from Fuel Combustion (IEA, 2018). The emissionsintensity was obtiained by dividing the final emissions by the GVA.
References:
IEA. (2018). Based on IEA data on World Energy Statistics and Balances 2018 Â© OECD/IEA[2018]; as modified by the Climate Action Tracker. Available at:  https://www.iea.org/statistics/co2emissions/

Source Description: Data on coal in primary energy supply (total, and coal, expressed as the sum of coal, coal products, peat and peat products taken together) were obtained from IEA data (IEA, 2019).
References: IEA. (2019). Based on IEA data from Energy Statistics and Balances 2019 Â© OECD/IEA[2019], www.iea.org/statistics, Licence: www.iea.org/t&c; as modified by the Climate Action Tracker.

Indicator Description: GHG emissions per unit of oil and gas produced
Source Description: This is calculated as the sum of fugitive emissions from oil and gas (EDGAR), emissions from gas flaring (NOAA) and other emissions from the oil and gas industriesâ€™ own use 3 (IEA) over domestic production of crude oil and natural gas.
References:
IEA. (2016). Based on IEA data from Energy Statistics and Balances 2016 Â© OECD/IEA[2016], www.iea.org/statistics, Licence: www.iea.org/t&c; as modified by the Climate Action Tracker. 

EDGAR database, available on http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/background.php

NOAA, satellite data available via http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/dmsp/interest/gas_flares.html

Indicator Description: Oil and Gas Production
Source Description: This number was obtained from IEA Energy Balances data (IEA, 2016).
References: IEA. (2016). Based on IEA data from Energy Statistics and Balances 2016 Â© OECD/IEA[2016], www.iea.org/statistics, Licence: www.iea.org/t&c; as modified by the Climate Action Tracker.

Indicator Description: Biofuels and electrification in aviation
Source Description: All historical data on fuel use in transport have been based on IEA data (IEA, 2016).
References: IEA. (2016). Based on IEA data from Energy Statistics and Balances 2016 Â© OECD/IEA[2016], www.iea.org/statistics, Licence: www.iea.org/t&c; as modified by the Climate Action Tracker.

Indicator Description: Passenger flux per capita
Source Description: All historical data on transport activity have been taken from ICCT 2014 Transport Roadmap Energy Model if available, and from the ICAO 2013, 2014 and 2015 Annual Reports where not, while population data are from UN World Population Prospects.
References: ICAO. (2014). Annual Report 2013 - Appendix 1. Available on http://www.icao.int/annual-report-2013/Documents/Appendix_1_en.pdfICAO. (2015). Annual Report 2014 - Appendix 1. Available on http://www.icao.int/annual-report-2014/Documents/Appendix_1_en.pdfICAO. (2016). Annual Report 2015 - Appendix 1. Available on http://www.icao.int/annual-report-2015/Documents/Appendix_1_en.pdfICCT. (2014). Transport Roadmap Energy Model.United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2015). World Population Prospects: The 2015 Revision, DVD Edition. Medium Fertility Variant. Link: https://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/Download/Standard/Population/

Indicator Description: Modal split
Source Description: The modal split was obtained by calculating the fractions of the activity of each category. All historical data on transport activity have been taken from ICCT 2014 Transport Roadmap Energy Model, apart from country-level data within the EU, which were taken from the TREMOVE model version 4.2. Data update on 30 July 2019, data extracted from UNECE (https://w3.unece.org/PXWeb2015/pxweb/en/STAT/STAT__40-TRTRANS__02-TRROAD/04_en_TRRoadPassgKm_r.px/table/tableViewLayout1/) and ITF-OECD (https://stats.ITF-OECD.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=ITF_INV-MTN_DATA). Data from 2014 was updated with data from ITF-OECD (2019).
References:
ITF-OECD, Key Transport Statistics 2018 Data (2019). Available at: https://www.itf-oecd.org/sites/default/files/docs/key-transport-statistics-2019_0.pdf

ICCT. (2017). Global Transportation Roadmap Model.
TREMOVE 4.2, Transport & Mobility, University of Leuven, http://www.tmleuven.be/methode/tremove/home.htm. UNECE (https://w3.unece.org/PXWeb2015/pxweb/en/STAT/STAT__40-TRTRANS__02-TRROAD/04_en_TRRoadPassgKm_r.px/). ITF-OECD (https://stats.ITF-OECD.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=ITF_INV-MTN_DATA)

Indicator Description: CO2 emission per vehicle kilometre
Source Description: Road transport emissions intensity was calculated by dividing the activity with the emissions data. Activity and emissions data between 2016-2017 was extracted from ITF-OECD and UNFCC respectively, for the following countries: USA, Japan, Australia, France, Italy and the UK. All historical data until 2014 on transport emissions have been taken from ICCT 2014 Transport Roadmap Energy Model, apart from country-level data within the EU, which were taken from the TREMOVE model version 4.2.
References:
ITF-OECD, (2019). Available at: https://www.itf-oecd.org/sites/default/files/docs/key-transport-statistics-2019_0.pdf

UNFCCC, GHG emissions (2019). Available at: https://di.unfccc.int/detailed_data_by_party

ICCT. (2017). Global Transportation Roadmap Model.
TREMOVE 4.2, Transport & Mobility, University of Leuven, http://www.tmleuven.be/methode/tremove/home.htm; UNFCCC, 2019 (https://di.unfccc.int/detailed_data_by_party); ITF-OECD, 2019 (https://www.itf-oecd.org/sites/default/files/docs/key-transport-statistics-2019_0.pdf)

Indicator Description: Biofuels and electrification in road transport
Source Description: Biofuel and electricity energy consumption in the road transport sector was summed and divided by total final consumption in the road transport sectotr. All data eas collected from IEA (2018).
References: IEA, World Energy Balances (2018). Available at: https://www.iea.org/statistics/balances/

Indicator Description: Amount of EVs per 1000 capita
Source Description: The EV per capita intensity was obtained from divinding the national EV stock by national population data. Data on EV stock was obtained from the IEA Global EV Outlook (IEA 2016; 2017; 2018; 2019). This indicator contains clues on the success of a country's EV supporting environment (and to a lesser extent, as well as on the fact that generally, the wealthier a country's population, the higher the amount of vehicles per capita).
References:
IEA, World EV Outlook (2019). Available at: https://www.iea.org/publications/reports/globalevoutlook2019/

IEA, World EV Outlook (2018). Available at: https://www.iea.org/gevo2018/

IEA, World EV Outlook (2017). Available at: https://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/GlobalEVOutlook2017.pdf

IEA, Global EV Outlook: Beyond One Million Electric Cars (2016). Available on https://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/Global_EV_Outlook_2016.pdf

United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division; World Population Prospects: The 2019 Revision (2019). Available at: https://population.un.org/wpp/Download/Standard/Population/

Indicator Description: Amount of public EV chargers per million capita
Source Description: EV chargers per capita intensity was obtained by dividing the amount of publicly available EV chargers in a country (IEA, 2019) by the national population (UN, 2019).
References:
IEA, World EV Outlook (2019). Available at: https://www.iea.org/publications/reports/globalevoutlook2019/

United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division; World Population Prospects: The 2019 Revision (2019). Available at: https://population.un.org/wpp/Download/Standard/Population/

Indicator Description: % of total market
Source Description: The EV market share data was collected from IEA (2019).
References: IEA, World EV Outlook (2019). Available at: https://www.iea.org/publications/reports/globalevoutlook2019/

Indicator Description: Amount of new EV sales, aggregated per country
Source Description: New EV sales data was collected from IEA (2019).
References: IEA, World EV Outlook (2019). Available at: https://www.iea.org/publications/reports/globalevoutlook2019/

Name of Indicator: New EV sales per million capita
Indicator Description: Amount of new EV sales per million capita
Source Description: EV sales per capita intensity was calculated by dividing the amount of new EV sales in a country (IEA, 2019) by the national population (UN, 2019).
References:
IEA, World EV Outlook (2019). Available at: https://www.iea.org/publications/reports/globalevoutlook2019/

United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division; World Population Prospects: The 2019 Revision (2019). Available at: https://population.un.org/wpp/Download/Standard/Population/

Indicator Description: Amount of waste per capita
Source Description: The total amount generated of municipal waste was obtained on country level from (OECD, 2015) and from the Waste Atlas for an estimation of the global number. Population data are from UN World Population Prospects.
References:
OECD. (2015). OECD Environment Statistics - Municipal waste. Retrieved May 18, 2015, from http://www.oecd-ilibrary.org/environment/data/oecd-environment-statistics/municipal-waste_data-00601-en

United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2015). World Population Prospects: The 2015 Revision, DVD Edition. Medium Fertility Variant. Link: https://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/Download/Standard/Population/

Waste Atlas. Global Waste Clock. Link: http://www.atlas.d-waste.com/

Indicator Description: Methane emissions per unit of waste
Source Description: For total amount generated of municipal waste: (OECD, 2015); for CH4 emission from solid waste: (JRC/PBL, 2012; UNFCCC, 2015); for worldwide waste generation, estimation from Waste Atlas.
References: JRC/PBL. (2012). Edgar Version 4.2 FT2010. Retrieved from http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/index.phpOECD. (2015). OECD Environment Statistics - Municipal waste. Retrieved May 18, 2015, from http://www.oecd-ilibrary.org/environment/data/oecd-environment-statistics/municipal-waste_data-00601-enUNFCCC. (2015). Greenhouse Gas Inventory Data. Greenhouse Gas Inventory Data. Retrieved from http://unfccc.int/di/DetailedByParty.doUnited Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Population Division (2015). World Population Prospects: The 2015 Revision, DVD Edition. Medium Fertility Variant. Link: https://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/Download/Standard/Population/Waste Atlas. Global Waste Clock. Link: http://www.atlas.d-waste.com/
